  14. (**************************************************************************)

  16. (** Large, multi-dimensional, numerical arrays.

  18.    This module implements multi-dimensional arrays of integers and
  19.    floating-point numbers, thereafter referred to as 'Bigarrays',
  20.    to distinguish them from the standard OCaml arrays described in
  21.    {!module:Array}.

  23.    The implementation allows efficient sharing of large numerical
  24.    arrays between OCaml code and C or Fortran numerical libraries.

  26.    The main differences between 'Bigarrays' and standard OCaml
  27.    arrays are as follows:
  28.    - Bigarrays are not limited in size, unlike OCaml arrays.
  29.      (Normal float arrays are limited to 2,097,151 elements on a 32-bit
  30.      platform, and normal arrays of other types to 4,194,303 elements.)
  31.    - Bigarrays are multi-dimensional.  Any number of dimensions
  32.      between 0 and 16 is supported.  In contrast, OCaml arrays
  33.      are mono-dimensional and require encoding multi-dimensional
  34.      arrays as arrays of arrays.
  35.    - Bigarrays can only contain integers and floating-point numbers,
  36.      while OCaml arrays can contain arbitrary OCaml data types.
  37.    - Bigarrays provide more space-efficient storage of
  38.      integer and floating-point elements than normal OCaml arrays, in
  39.      particular because they support 'small' types such as
  40.      single-precision floats and 8 and 16-bit integers, in addition to
  41.      the standard OCaml types of double-precision floats and 32 and
  42.      64-bit integers.
  43.    - The memory layout of Bigarrays is entirely compatible with that
  44.      of arrays in C and Fortran, allowing large arrays to be passed
  45.      back and forth between OCaml code and C / Fortran code with no
  46.      data copying at all.
  47.    - Bigarrays support interesting high-level operations that normal
  48.      arrays do not provide efficiently, such as extracting sub-arrays
  49.      and 'slicing' a multi-dimensional array along certain dimensions,
  50.      all without any copying.

  52.    Users of this module are encouraged to do [open Bigarray] in their
  53.    source, then refer to array types and operations via short dot
  54.    notation, e.g. [Array1.t] or [Array2.sub].

  56.    Bigarrays support all the OCaml ad-hoc polymorphic operations:
  57.    - comparisons ([=], [<>], [<=], etc, as well as {!Stdlib.compare});
  58.    - hashing (module [Hash]);
  59.    - and structured input-output (the functions from the
  60.      {!Marshal} module, as well as {!Stdlib.output_value}
  61.      and {!Stdlib.input_value}).
  62. *)

  64. (** {1 Element kinds} *)

  66. (** Bigarrays can contain elements of the following kinds:
  67. - IEEE single precision (32 bits) floating-point numbers
  68.    ({!Bigarray.float32_elt}),
  69. - IEEE double precision (64 bits) floating-point numbers
  70.    ({!Bigarray.float64_elt}),
  71. - IEEE single precision (2 * 32 bits) floating-point complex numbers
  72.    ({!Bigarray.complex32_elt}),
  73. - IEEE double precision (2 * 64 bits) floating-point complex numbers
  74.    ({!Bigarray.complex64_elt}),
  75. - 8-bit integers (signed or unsigned)
  76.    ({!Bigarray.int8_signed_elt} or {!Bigarray.int8_unsigned_elt}),
  77. - 16-bit integers (signed or unsigned)
  78.    ({!Bigarray.int16_signed_elt} or {!Bigarray.int16_unsigned_elt}),
  79. - OCaml integers (signed, 31 bits on 32-bit architectures,
  80.    63 bits on 64-bit architectures) ({!Bigarray.int_elt}),
  81. - 32-bit signed integers ({!Bigarray.int32_elt}),
  82. - 64-bit signed integers ({!Bigarray.int64_elt}),
  83. - platform-native signed integers (32 bits on 32-bit architectures,
  84.    64 bits on 64-bit architectures) ({!Bigarray.nativeint_elt}).

  86.    Each element kind is represented at the type level by one of the
  87.    [*_elt] types defined below (defined with a single constructor instead
  88.    of abstract types for technical injectivity reasons).

  90.    @since 4.07 Moved from otherlibs to stdlib.
  91. *)

  93. ‌type float32_elt = Float32_elt
  94. ‌type float64_elt = Float64_elt
  95. ‌type int8_signed_elt = Int8_signed_elt
  96. ‌type int8_unsigned_elt = Int8_unsigned_elt
  97. ‌type int16_signed_elt = Int16_signed_elt
  98. ‌type int16_unsigned_elt = Int16_unsigned_elt
  99. ‌type int32_elt = Int32_elt
  100. ‌type int64_elt = Int64_elt
  101. ‌type int_elt = Int_elt
  102. ‌type nativeint_elt = Nativeint_elt
  103. ‌type complex32_elt = Complex32_elt
  104. ‌type complex64_elt = Complex64_elt

  106. ‌type ('a, 'b) kind =
  107.     Float32 : (float, float32_elt) kind
  108.   | Float64 : (float, float64_elt) kind
  109.   | Int8_signed : (int, int8_signed_elt) kind
  110.   | Int8_unsigned : (int, int8_unsigned_elt) kind
  111.   | Int16_signed : (int, int16_signed_elt) kind
  112.   | Int16_unsigned : (int, int16_unsigned_elt) kind
  113.   | Int32 : (int32, int32_elt) kind
  114.   | Int64 : (int64, int64_elt) kind
  115.   | Int : (int, int_elt) kind
  116.   | Nativeint : (nativeint, nativeint_elt) kind
  117.   | Complex32 : (Complex.t, complex32_elt) kind
  118.   | Complex64 : (Complex.t, complex64_elt) kind
  119.   | Char : (char, int8_unsigned_elt) kind (**)
  120. (** To each element kind is associated an OCaml type, which is
  121.    the type of OCaml values that can be stored in the Bigarray
  122.    or read back from it.  This type is not necessarily the same
  123.    as the type of the array elements proper: for instance,
  124.    a Bigarray whose elements are of kind [float32_elt] contains
  125.    32-bit single precision floats, but reading or writing one of
  126.    its elements from OCaml uses the OCaml type [float], which is
  127.    64-bit double precision floats.

  129.    The GADT type [('a, 'b) kind] captures this association
  130.    of an OCaml type ['a] for values read or written in the Bigarray,
  131.    and of an element kind ['b] which represents the actual contents
  132.    of the Bigarray. Its constructors list all possible associations
  133.    of OCaml types with element kinds, and are re-exported below for
  134.    backward-compatibility reasons.

  136.    Using a generalized algebraic datatype (GADT) here allows writing
  137.    well-typed polymorphic functions whose return type depend on the
  138.    argument type, such as:

  140. {[
  141.   let zero : type a b. (a, b) kind -> a = function
  142.     | Float32 -> 0.0 | Complex32 -> Complex.zero
  143.     | Float64 -> 0.0 | Complex64 -> Complex.zero
  144.     | Int8_signed -> 0 | Int8_unsigned -> 0
  145.     | Int16_signed -> 0 | Int16_unsigned -> 0
  146.     | Int32 -> 0l | Int64 -> 0L
  147.     | Int -> 0 | Nativeint -> 0n
  148.     | Char -> '\000'
  149. ]}
  150. *)

  152. ‌val float32 : (float, float32_elt) kind
  153. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  155. ‌val float64 : (float, float64_elt) kind
  156. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  158. ‌val complex32 : (Complex.t, complex32_elt) kind
  159. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  161. ‌val complex64 : (Complex.t, complex64_elt) kind
  162. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  164. ‌val int8_signed : (int, int8_signed_elt) kind
  165. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  167. ‌val int8_unsigned : (int, int8_unsigned_elt) kind
  168. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  170. ‌val int16_signed : (int, int16_signed_elt) kind
  171. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  173. ‌val int16_unsigned : (int, int16_unsigned_elt) kind
  174. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  176. ‌val int : (int, int_elt) kind
  177. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  179. ‌val int32 : (int32, int32_elt) kind
  180. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  182. ‌val int64 : (int64, int64_elt) kind
  183. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  185. ‌val nativeint : (nativeint, nativeint_elt) kind
  186. (** See {!Bigarray.char}. *)

  188. ‌val char : (char, int8_unsigned_elt) kind
  189. (** As shown by the types of the values above,
  190.    Bigarrays of kind [float32_elt] and [float64_elt] are
  191.    accessed using the OCaml type [float].  Bigarrays of complex kinds
  192.    [complex32_elt], [complex64_elt] are accessed with the OCaml type
  193.    {!Complex.t}. Bigarrays of
  194.    integer kinds are accessed using the smallest OCaml integer
  195.    type large enough to represent the array elements:
  196.    [int] for 8- and 16-bit integer Bigarrays, as well as OCaml-integer
  197.    Bigarrays; [int32] for 32-bit integer Bigarrays; [int64]
  198.    for 64-bit integer Bigarrays; and [nativeint] for
  199.    platform-native integer Bigarrays.  Finally, Bigarrays of
  200.    kind [int8_unsigned_elt] can also be accessed as arrays of
  201.    characters instead of arrays of small integers, by using
  202.    the kind value [char] instead of [int8_unsigned]. *)

  204. ‌val kind_size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b) kind -> int
  205. (** [kind_size_in_bytes k] is the number of bytes used to store
  206.    an element of type [k].

  208.    @since 4.03 *)

  210. (** {1 Array layouts} *)

  212. ‌type c_layout = C_layout_typ (**)
  213. (** See {!type:Bigarray.fortran_layout}.*)

  215. ‌type fortran_layout = Fortran_layout_typ (**)
  216. (** To facilitate interoperability with existing C and Fortran code,
  217.    this library supports two different memory layouts for Bigarrays,
  218.    one compatible with the C conventions,
  219.    the other compatible with the Fortran conventions.

  221.    In the C-style layout, array indices start at 0, and
  222.    multi-dimensional arrays are laid out in row-major format.
  223.    That is, for a two-dimensional array, all elements of
  224.    row 0 are contiguous in memory, followed by all elements of
  225.    row 1, etc.  In other terms, the array elements at [(x,y)]
  226.    and [(x, y+1)] are adjacent in memory.

  228.    In the Fortran-style layout, array indices start at 1, and
  229.    multi-dimensional arrays are laid out in column-major format.
  230.    That is, for a two-dimensional array, all elements of
  231.    column 0 are contiguous in memory, followed by all elements of
  232.    column 1, etc.  In other terms, the array elements at [(x,y)]
  233.    and [(x+1, y)] are adjacent in memory.

  235.    Each layout style is identified at the type level by the
  236.    phantom types {!type:Bigarray.c_layout} and {!type:Bigarray.fortran_layout}
  237.    respectively. *)

  239. (** {2 Supported layouts}

  241.    The GADT type ['a layout] represents one of the two supported
  242.    memory layouts: C-style or Fortran-style. Its constructors are
  243.    re-exported as values below for backward-compatibility reasons.
  244. *)

  246. ‌type 'a layout =
  247.     C_layout: c_layout layout
  248.   | Fortran_layout: fortran_layout layout

  250. ‌val c_layout : c_layout layout
  251. ‌val fortran_layout : fortran_layout layout


  254. (** {1 Generic arrays (of arbitrarily many dimensions)} *)

  256. module Genarray :
  257.   sig
  258.   type (!'a, !'b, !'c) t
  259.   (** The type [Genarray.t] is the type of Bigarrays with variable
  260.      numbers of dimensions.  Any number of dimensions between 0 and 16
  261.      is supported.

  263.      The three type parameters to [Genarray.t] identify the array element
  264.      kind and layout, as follows:
  265.      - the first parameter, ['a], is the OCaml type for accessing array
  266.        elements ([float], [int], [int32], [int64], [nativeint]);
  267.      - the second parameter, ['b], is the actual kind of array elements
  268.        ([float32_elt], [float64_elt], [int8_signed_elt], [int8_unsigned_elt],
  269.        etc);
  270.      - the third parameter, ['c], identifies the array layout
  271.        ([c_layout] or [fortran_layout]).

  273.      For instance, [(float, float32_elt, fortran_layout) Genarray.t]
  274.      is the type of generic Bigarrays containing 32-bit floats
  275.      in Fortran layout; reads and writes in this array use the
  276.      OCaml type [float]. *)

  278.   external create: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> int array -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  279.     = "caml_ba_create"
  280.   (** [Genarray.create kind layout dimensions] returns a new Bigarray
  281.      whose element kind is determined by the parameter [kind] (one of
  282.      [float32], [float64], [int8_signed], etc) and whose layout is
  283.      determined by the parameter [layout] (one of [c_layout] or
  284.      [fortran_layout]).  The [dimensions] parameter is an array of
  285.      integers that indicate the size of the Bigarray in each dimension.
  286.      The length of [dimensions] determines the number of dimensions
  287.      of the Bigarray.

  289.      For instance, [Genarray.create int32 c_layout [|4;6;8|]]
  290.      returns a fresh Bigarray of 32-bit integers, in C layout,
  291.      having three dimensions, the three dimensions being 4, 6 and 8
  292.      respectively.

  294.      Bigarrays returned by [Genarray.create] are not initialized:
  295.      the initial values of array elements is unspecified.

  297.      [Genarray.create] raises [Invalid_argument] if the number of dimensions
  298.      is not in the range 0 to 16 inclusive, or if one of the dimensions
  299.      is negative. *)

  301. ‌  val init: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> int array -> (int array -> 'a) ->
  302.             ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  303.   (** [Genarray.init kind layout dimensions f] returns a new Bigarray [b]
  304.       whose element kind is determined by the parameter [kind] (one of
  305.       [float32], [float64], [int8_signed], etc) and whose layout is
  306.       determined by the parameter [layout] (one of [c_layout] or
  307.       [fortran_layout]).  The [dimensions] parameter is an array of
  308.       integers that indicate the size of the Bigarray in each dimension.
  309.       The length of [dimensions] determines the number of dimensions
  310.       of the Bigarray.

  312.       Each element [Genarray.get b i] is initialized to the result of [f i].
  313.       In other words, [Genarray.init kind layout dimensions f] tabulates
  314.       the results of [f] applied to the indices of a new Bigarray whose
  315.       layout is described by [kind], [layout] and [dimensions].  The index
  316.       array [i] may be shared and mutated between calls to f.

  318.       For instance, [Genarray.init int c_layout [|2; 1; 3|]
  319.       (Array.fold_left (+) 0)] returns a fresh Bigarray of integers, in C
  320.       layout, having three dimensions (2, 1, 3, respectively), with the
  321.       element values 0, 1, 2, 1, 2, 3.

  323.       [Genarray.init] raises [Invalid_argument] if the number of dimensions
  324.       is not in the range 0 to 16 inclusive, or if one of the dimensions
  325.       is negative.

  327.       @since 4.12 *)

  329.   external num_dims: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "caml_ba_num_dims"
  330.   (** Return the number of dimensions of the given Bigarray. *)

  332.   val dims : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int array
  333.   (** [Genarray.dims a] returns all dimensions of the Bigarray [a],
  334.      as an array of integers of length [Genarray.num_dims a]. *)

  336.   external nth_dim: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int = "caml_ba_dim"
  337.   (** [Genarray.nth_dim a n] returns the [n]-th dimension of the
  338.      Bigarray [a].  The first dimension corresponds to [n = 0];
  339.      the second dimension corresponds to [n = 1]; the last dimension,
  340.      to [n = Genarray.num_dims a - 1].
  341.      @raise Invalid_argument if [n] is less than 0 or greater or equal than
  342.      [Genarray.num_dims a]. *)

  344.   external kind: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b) kind = "caml_ba_kind"
  345.   (** Return the kind of the given Bigarray. *)

  347.   external layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'c layout = "caml_ba_layout"
  348.   (** Return the layout of the given Bigarray. *)

  350.   external change_layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'd layout -> ('a, 'b, 'd) t
  351.       = "caml_ba_change_layout"
  352.   (** [Genarray.change_layout a layout] returns a Bigarray with the
  353.       specified [layout], sharing the data with [a] (and hence having
  354.       the same dimensions as [a]). No copying of elements is involved: the
  355.       new array and the original array share the same storage space.
  356.       The dimensions are reversed, such that [get v [| a; b |]] in
  357.       C layout becomes [get v [| b+1; a+1 |]] in Fortran layout.

  359.       @since 4.04
  360.   *)

  362.   val size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int
  363.   (** [size_in_bytes a] is the number of elements in [a] multiplied
  364.     by [a]'s {!kind_size_in_bytes}.

  366.     @since 4.03 *)

  368.   external get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int array -> 'a = "caml_ba_get_generic"
  369.   (** Read an element of a generic Bigarray.
  370.      [Genarray.get a [|i1; ...; iN|]] returns the element of [a]
  371.      whose coordinates are [i1] in the first dimension, [i2] in
  372.      the second dimension, ..., [iN] in the [N]-th dimension.

  374.      If [a] has C layout, the coordinates must be greater or equal than 0
  375.      and strictly less than the corresponding dimensions of [a].
  376.      If [a] has Fortran layout, the coordinates must be greater or equal
  377.      than 1 and less or equal than the corresponding dimensions of [a].

  379.      If [N > 3], alternate syntax is provided: you can write
  380.      [a.{i1, i2, ..., iN}] instead of [Genarray.get a [|i1; ...; iN|]].
  381.      (The syntax [a.{...}] with one, two or three coordinates is
  382.      reserved for accessing one-, two- and three-dimensional arrays
  383.      as described below.)

  385.      @raise Invalid_argument if the array [a] does not have exactly [N]
  386.      dimensions, or if the coordinates are outside the array bounds.
  387.   *)

  389.   external set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int array -> 'a -> unit
  390.     = "caml_ba_set_generic"
  391.   (** Assign an element of a generic Bigarray.
  392.      [Genarray.set a [|i1; ...; iN|] v] stores the value [v] in the
  393.      element of [a] whose coordinates are [i1] in the first dimension,
  394.      [i2] in the second dimension, ..., [iN] in the [N]-th dimension.

  396.      The array [a] must have exactly [N] dimensions, and all coordinates
  397.      must lie inside the array bounds, as described for [Genarray.get];
  398.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised.

  400.      If [N > 3], alternate syntax is provided: you can write
  401.      [a.{i1, i2, ..., iN} <- v] instead of
  402.      [Genarray.set a [|i1; ...; iN|] v].
  403.      (The syntax [a.{...} <- v] with one, two or three coordinates is
  404.      reserved for updating one-, two- and three-dimensional arrays
  405.      as described below.) *)

  407.   external sub_left: ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) t
  408.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  409.   (** Extract a sub-array of the given Bigarray by restricting the
  410.      first (left-most) dimension.  [Genarray.sub_left a ofs len]
  411.      returns a Bigarray with the same number of dimensions as [a],
  412.      and the same dimensions as [a], except the first dimension,
  413.      which corresponds to the interval [[ofs ... ofs + len - 1]]
  414.      of the first dimension of [a].  No copying of elements is
  415.      involved: the sub-array and the original array share the same
  416.      storage space.  In other terms, the element at coordinates
  417.      [[|i1; ...; iN|]] of the sub-array is identical to the
  418.      element at coordinates [[|i1+ofs; ...; iN|]] of the original
  419.      array [a].

  421.      [Genarray.sub_left] applies only to Bigarrays in C layout.
  422.      @raise Invalid_argument if [ofs] and [len] do not designate
  423.      a valid sub-array of [a], that is, if [ofs < 0], or [len < 0],
  424.      or [ofs + len > Genarray.nth_dim a 0]. *)

  426.   external sub_right:
  427.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t
  428.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  429.   (** Extract a sub-array of the given Bigarray by restricting the
  430.      last (right-most) dimension.  [Genarray.sub_right a ofs len]
  431.      returns a Bigarray with the same number of dimensions as [a],
  432.      and the same dimensions as [a], except the last dimension,
  433.      which corresponds to the interval [[ofs ... ofs + len - 1]]
  434.      of the last dimension of [a].  No copying of elements is
  435.      involved: the sub-array and the original array share the same
  436.      storage space.  In other terms, the element at coordinates
  437.      [[|i1; ...; iN|]] of the sub-array is identical to the
  438.      element at coordinates [[|i1; ...; iN+ofs|]] of the original
  439.      array [a].

  441.      [Genarray.sub_right] applies only to Bigarrays in Fortran layout.
  442.      @raise Invalid_argument if [ofs] and [len] do not designate
  443.      a valid sub-array of [a], that is, if [ofs < 1], or [len < 0],
  444.      or [ofs + len > Genarray.nth_dim a (Genarray.num_dims a - 1)]. *)

  446.   external slice_left:
  447.     ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int array -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) t
  448.     = "caml_ba_slice"
  449.   (** Extract a sub-array of lower dimension from the given Bigarray
  450.      by fixing one or several of the first (left-most) coordinates.
  451.      [Genarray.slice_left a [|i1; ... ; iM|]] returns the 'slice'
  452.      of [a] obtained by setting the first [M] coordinates to
  453.      [i1], ..., [iM].  If [a] has [N] dimensions, the slice has
  454.      dimension [N - M], and the element at coordinates
  455.      [[|j1; ...; j(N-M)|]] in the slice is identical to the element
  456.      at coordinates [[|i1; ...; iM; j1; ...; j(N-M)|]] in the original
  457.      array [a].  No copying of elements is involved: the slice and
  458.      the original array share the same storage space.

  460.      [Genarray.slice_left] applies only to Bigarrays in C layout.
  461.      @raise Invalid_argument if [M >= N], or if [[|i1; ... ; iM|]]
  462.      is outside the bounds of [a]. *)

  464.   external slice_right:
  465.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int array -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t
  466.     = "caml_ba_slice"
  467.   (** Extract a sub-array of lower dimension from the given Bigarray
  468.      by fixing one or several of the last (right-most) coordinates.
  469.      [Genarray.slice_right a [|i1; ... ; iM|]] returns the 'slice'
  470.      of [a] obtained by setting the last [M] coordinates to
  471.      [i1], ..., [iM].  If [a] has [N] dimensions, the slice has
  472.      dimension [N - M], and the element at coordinates
  473.      [[|j1; ...; j(N-M)|]] in the slice is identical to the element
  474.      at coordinates [[|j1; ...; j(N-M); i1; ...; iM|]] in the original
  475.      array [a].  No copying of elements is involved: the slice and
  476.      the original array share the same storage space.

  478.      [Genarray.slice_right] applies only to Bigarrays in Fortran layout.
  479.      @raise Invalid_argument if [M >= N], or if [[|i1; ... ; iM|]]
  480.      is outside the bounds of [a]. *)

  482.   external blit: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> unit
  483.       = "caml_ba_blit"
  484.   (** Copy all elements of a Bigarray in another Bigarray.
  485.      [Genarray.blit src dst] copies all elements of [src] into
  486.      [dst].  Both arrays [src] and [dst] must have the same number of
  487.      dimensions and equal dimensions.  Copying a sub-array of [src]
  488.      to a sub-array of [dst] can be achieved by applying [Genarray.blit]
  489.      to sub-array or slices of [src] and [dst]. *)

  491.   external fill: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit = "caml_ba_fill"
  492.   (** Set all elements of a Bigarray to a given value.
  493.      [Genarray.fill a v] stores the value [v] in all elements of
  494.      the Bigarray [a].  Setting only some elements of [a] to [v]
  495.      can be achieved by applying [Genarray.fill] to a sub-array
  496.      or a slice of [a]. *)
  497.   end

  499. (** {1 Zero-dimensional arrays} *)

  501. (** Zero-dimensional arrays. The [Array0] structure provides operations
  502.    similar to those of {!Bigarray.Genarray}, but specialized to the case
  503.    of zero-dimensional arrays that only contain a single scalar value.
  504.    Statically knowing the number of dimensions of the array allows
  505.    faster operations, and more precise static type-checking.
  506.    @since 4.05 *)
  507. module Array0 : sig
  508.   type (!'a, !'b, !'c) t
  509.   (** The type of zero-dimensional Bigarrays whose elements have
  510.      OCaml type ['a], representation kind ['b], and memory layout ['c]. *)

  512.   val create: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  513.   (** [Array0.create kind layout] returns a new Bigarray of zero dimension.
  514.      [kind] and [layout] determine the array element kind and the array
  515.      layout as described for {!Genarray.create}. *)

  517.   val init: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> 'a -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  518.   (** [Array0.init kind layout v] behaves like [Array0.create kind layout]
  519.      except that the element is additionally initialized to the value [v].

  521.      @since 4.12 *)

  523.   external kind: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b) kind = "caml_ba_kind"
  524.   (** Return the kind of the given Bigarray. *)

  526.   external layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'c layout = "caml_ba_layout"
  527.   (** Return the layout of the given Bigarray. *)

  529. ‌  val change_layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'd layout -> ('a, 'b, 'd) t
  530.   (** [Array0.change_layout a layout] returns a Bigarray with the
  531.       specified [layout], sharing the data with [a]. No copying of elements
  532.       is involved: the new array and the original array share the same
  533.       storage space.

  535.       @since 4.06
  536.   *)

  538. ‌  val size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int
  539.   (** [size_in_bytes a] is [a]'s {!kind_size_in_bytes}. *)

  541. ‌  val get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a
  542.   (** [Array0.get a] returns the only element in [a]. *)

  544. ‌  val set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit
  545.   (** [Array0.set a x v] stores the value [v] in [a]. *)

  547.   external blit: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> unit = "caml_ba_blit"
  548.   (** Copy the first Bigarray to the second Bigarray.
  549.      See {!Genarray.blit} for more details. *)

  551.   external fill: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit = "caml_ba_fill"
  552.   (** Fill the given Bigarray with the given value.
  553.      See {!Genarray.fill} for more details. *)

  555.   val of_value: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> 'a -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  556.   (** Build a zero-dimensional Bigarray initialized from the
  557.      given value.  *)

  559. end


  562. (** {1 One-dimensional arrays} *)

  564. (** One-dimensional arrays. The [Array1] structure provides operations
  565.    similar to those of
  566.    {!Bigarray.Genarray}, but specialized to the case of one-dimensional arrays.
  567.    (The {!Array2} and {!Array3} structures below provide operations
  568.    specialized for two- and three-dimensional arrays.)
  569.    Statically knowing the number of dimensions of the array allows
  570.    faster operations, and more precise static type-checking. *)
  571. module Array1 : sig
  572.   type (!'a, !'b, !'c) t
  573.   (** The type of one-dimensional Bigarrays whose elements have
  574.      OCaml type ['a], representation kind ['b], and memory layout ['c]. *)

  576.   val create: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  577.   (** [Array1.create kind layout dim] returns a new Bigarray of
  578.      one dimension, whose size is [dim].  [kind] and [layout]
  579.      determine the array element kind and the array layout
  580.      as described for {!Genarray.create}. *)

  582.   val init: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> int -> (int -> 'a) ->
  583.             ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  584.   (** [Array1.init kind layout dim f] returns a new Bigarray [b]
  585.      of one dimension, whose size is [dim].  [kind] and [layout]
  586.      determine the array element kind and the array layout
  587.      as described for {!Genarray.create}.

  589.      Each element [Array1.get b i] of the array is initialized to the
  590.      result of [f i].

  592.      In other words, [Array1.init kind layout dimensions f] tabulates
  593.      the results of [f] applied to the indices of a new Bigarray whose
  594.      layout is described by [kind], [layout] and [dim].

  596.      @since 4.12 *)

  598.   external dim: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_1"
  599.   (** Return the size (dimension) of the given one-dimensional
  600.      Bigarray. *)

  602.   external kind: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b) kind = "caml_ba_kind"
  603.   (** Return the kind of the given Bigarray. *)

  605.   external layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'c layout = "caml_ba_layout"
  606.   (** Return the layout of the given Bigarray. *)

  608. ‌  val change_layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'd layout -> ('a, 'b, 'd) t
  609.   (** [Array1.change_layout a layout] returns a Bigarray with the
  610.       specified [layout], sharing the data with [a] (and hence having
  611.       the same dimension as [a]). No copying of elements is involved: the
  612.       new array and the original array share the same storage space.

  614.       @since 4.06
  615.   *)


  618. ‌  val size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int
  619.   (** [size_in_bytes a] is the number of elements in [a]
  620.     multiplied by [a]'s {!kind_size_in_bytes}.

  622.     @since 4.03 *)

  624.   external get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> 'a = "%caml_ba_ref_1"
  625.   (** [Array1.get a x], or alternatively [a.{x}],
  626.      returns the element of [a] at index [x].
  627.      [x] must be greater or equal than [0] and strictly less than
  628.      [Array1.dim a] if [a] has C layout.  If [a] has Fortran layout,
  629.      [x] must be greater or equal than [1] and less or equal than
  630.      [Array1.dim a].  Otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  632.   external set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> 'a -> unit = "%caml_ba_set_1"
  633.   (** [Array1.set a x v], also written [a.{x} <- v],
  634.      stores the value [v] at index [x] in [a].
  635.      [x] must be inside the bounds of [a] as described in
  636.      {!Bigarray.Array1.get};
  637.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  639.   external sub: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  640.       = "caml_ba_sub"
  641.   (** Extract a sub-array of the given one-dimensional Bigarray.
  642.      See {!Genarray.sub_left} for more details. *)

  644.   val slice: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array0.t
  645.   (** Extract a scalar (zero-dimensional slice) of the given one-dimensional
  646.      Bigarray.  The integer parameter is the index of the scalar to
  647.      extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_left} and
  648.      {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_right} for more details.
  649.      @since 4.05 *)

  651.   external blit: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> unit
  652.       = "caml_ba_blit"
  653.   (** Copy the first Bigarray to the second Bigarray.
  654.      See {!Genarray.blit} for more details. *)

  656.   external fill: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit = "caml_ba_fill"
  657.   (** Fill the given Bigarray with the given value.
  658.      See {!Genarray.fill} for more details. *)

  660.   val of_array: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> 'a array -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  661.   (** Build a one-dimensional Bigarray initialized from the
  662.      given array.  *)

  664.   external unsafe_get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> 'a = "%caml_ba_unsafe_ref_1"
  665.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array1.get}, but bounds checking is not always performed.
  666.       Use with caution and only when the program logic guarantees that
  667.       the access is within bounds. *)

  669.   external unsafe_set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> 'a -> unit
  670.                      = "%caml_ba_unsafe_set_1"
  671.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array1.set}, but bounds checking is not always performed.
  672.       Use with caution and only when the program logic guarantees that
  673.       the access is within bounds. *)

  675. end


  678. (** {1 Two-dimensional arrays} *)

  680. (** Two-dimensional arrays. The [Array2] structure provides operations
  681.    similar to those of {!Bigarray.Genarray}, but specialized to the
  682.    case of two-dimensional arrays. *)
  683. module Array2 :
  684.   sig
  685.   type (!'a, !'b, !'c) t
  686.   (** The type of two-dimensional Bigarrays whose elements have
  687.      OCaml type ['a], representation kind ['b], and memory layout ['c]. *)

  689.   val create: ('a, 'b) kind ->  'c layout -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  690.   (** [Array2.create kind layout dim1 dim2] returns a new Bigarray of
  691.      two dimensions, whose size is [dim1] in the first dimension
  692.      and [dim2] in the second dimension.  [kind] and [layout]
  693.      determine the array element kind and the array layout
  694.      as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.create}. *)

  696.   val init: ('a, 'b) kind ->  'c layout -> int -> int ->
  697.             (int -> int -> 'a) -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  698.   (** [Array2.init kind layout dim1 dim2 f] returns a new Bigarray [b]
  699.      of two dimensions, whose size is [dim2] in the first dimension
  700.      and [dim2] in the second dimension.  [kind] and [layout]
  701.      determine the array element kind and the array layout
  702.      as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.create}.

  704.      Each element [Array2.get b i j] of the array is initialized to
  705.      the result of [f i j].

  707.      In other words, [Array2.init kind layout dim1 dim2 f] tabulates
  708.      the results of [f] applied to the indices of a new Bigarray whose
  709.      layout is described by [kind], [layout], [dim1] and [dim2].

  711.      @since 4.12 *)

  713.   external dim1: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_1"
  714.   (** Return the first dimension of the given two-dimensional Bigarray. *)

  716.   external dim2: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_2"
  717.   (** Return the second dimension of the given two-dimensional Bigarray. *)

  719.   external kind: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b) kind = "caml_ba_kind"
  720.   (** Return the kind of the given Bigarray. *)

  722.   external layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'c layout = "caml_ba_layout"
  723.   (** Return the layout of the given Bigarray. *)

  725. ‌  val change_layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'd layout -> ('a, 'b, 'd) t
  726.   (** [Array2.change_layout a layout] returns a Bigarray with the
  727.       specified [layout], sharing the data with [a] (and hence having
  728.       the same dimensions as [a]). No copying of elements is involved: the
  729.       new array and the original array share the same storage space.
  730.       The dimensions are reversed, such that [get v [| a; b |]] in
  731.       C layout becomes [get v [| b+1; a+1 |]] in Fortran layout.

  733.       @since 4.06
  734.   *)


  737. ‌  val size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int
  738.   (** [size_in_bytes a] is the number of elements in [a]
  739.     multiplied by [a]'s {!kind_size_in_bytes}.

  741.     @since 4.03 *)

  743.   external get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> 'a = "%caml_ba_ref_2"
  744.   (** [Array2.get a x y], also written [a.{x,y}],
  745.      returns the element of [a] at coordinates ([x], [y]).
  746.      [x] and [y] must be within the bounds
  747.      of [a], as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.get};
  748.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  750.   external set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> 'a -> unit = "%caml_ba_set_2"
  751.   (** [Array2.set a x y v], or alternatively [a.{x,y} <- v],
  752.      stores the value [v] at coordinates ([x], [y]) in [a].
  753.      [x] and [y] must be within the bounds of [a],
  754.      as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.set};
  755.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  757.   external sub_left: ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) t
  758.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  759.   (** Extract a two-dimensional sub-array of the given two-dimensional
  760.      Bigarray by restricting the first dimension.
  761.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.sub_left} for more details.
  762.      [Array2.sub_left] applies only to arrays with C layout. *)

  764.   external sub_right:
  765.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t
  766.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  767.   (** Extract a two-dimensional sub-array of the given two-dimensional
  768.      Bigarray by restricting the second dimension.
  769.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.sub_right} for more details.
  770.      [Array2.sub_right] applies only to arrays with Fortran layout. *)

  772.   val slice_left: ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) Array1.t
  773.   (** Extract a row (one-dimensional slice) of the given two-dimensional
  774.      Bigarray.  The integer parameter is the index of the row to
  775.      extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_left} for more details.
  776.      [Array2.slice_left] applies only to arrays with C layout. *)

  778.   val slice_right:
  779.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) Array1.t
  780.   (** Extract a column (one-dimensional slice) of the given
  781.      two-dimensional Bigarray.  The integer parameter is the
  782.      index of the column to extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_right}
  783.      for more details.  [Array2.slice_right] applies only to arrays
  784.      with Fortran layout. *)

  786.   external blit: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> unit
  787.     = "caml_ba_blit"
  788.   (** Copy the first Bigarray to the second Bigarray.
  789.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.blit} for more details. *)

  791.   external fill: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit = "caml_ba_fill"
  792.   (** Fill the given Bigarray with the given value.
  793.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.fill} for more details. *)

  795.   val of_array: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> 'a array array -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  796.   (** Build a two-dimensional Bigarray initialized from the
  797.      given array of arrays.  *)

  799.   external unsafe_get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> 'a
  800.                      = "%caml_ba_unsafe_ref_2"
  801.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array2.get}, but bounds checking is not always
  802.       performed. *)

  804.   external unsafe_set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> 'a -> unit
  805.                      = "%caml_ba_unsafe_set_2"
  806.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array2.set}, but bounds checking is not always
  807.       performed. *)

  809. end

  811. (** {1 Three-dimensional arrays} *)

  813. (** Three-dimensional arrays. The [Array3] structure provides operations
  814.    similar to those of {!Bigarray.Genarray}, but specialized to the case
  815.    of three-dimensional arrays. *)
  816. module Array3 :
  817.   sig
  818.   type (!'a, !'b, !'c) t
  819.   (** The type of three-dimensional Bigarrays whose elements have
  820.      OCaml type ['a], representation kind ['b], and memory layout ['c]. *)

  822.   val create: ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> int -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  823.   (** [Array3.create kind layout dim1 dim2 dim3] returns a new Bigarray of
  824.      three dimensions, whose size is [dim1] in the first dimension,
  825.      [dim2] in the second dimension, and [dim3] in the third.
  826.      [kind] and [layout] determine the array element kind and
  827.      the array layout as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.create}. *)

  829.   val init: ('a, 'b) kind ->  'c layout -> int -> int -> int ->
  830.             (int -> int -> int -> 'a) -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  831.   (** [Array3.init kind layout dim1 dim2 dim3 f] returns a new Bigarray [b]
  832.      of three dimensions, whose size is [dim1] in the first dimension,
  833.      [dim2] in the second dimension, and [dim3] in the third.
  834.      [kind] and [layout] determine the array element kind and the array
  835.      layout as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.create}.

  837.      Each element [Array3.get b i j k] of the array is initialized to
  838.      the result of [f i j k].

  840.      In other words, [Array3.init kind layout dim1 dim2 dim3 f] tabulates
  841.      the results of [f] applied to the indices of a new Bigarray whose
  842.      layout is described by [kind], [layout], [dim1], [dim2] and [dim3].

  844.      @since 4.12 *)

  846.   external dim1: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_1"
  847.   (** Return the first dimension of the given three-dimensional Bigarray. *)

  849.   external dim2: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_2"
  850.   (** Return the second dimension of the given three-dimensional Bigarray. *)

  852.   external dim3: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int = "%caml_ba_dim_3"
  853.   (** Return the third dimension of the given three-dimensional Bigarray. *)

  855.   external kind: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b) kind = "caml_ba_kind"
  856.   (** Return the kind of the given Bigarray. *)

  858.   external layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'c layout = "caml_ba_layout"
  859.   (** Return the layout of the given Bigarray. *)


  862. ‌  val change_layout: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'd layout -> ('a, 'b, 'd) t
  863.   (** [Array3.change_layout a layout] returns a Bigarray with the
  864.       specified [layout], sharing the data with [a] (and hence having
  865.       the same dimensions as [a]). No copying of elements is involved: the
  866.       new array and the original array share the same storage space.
  867.       The dimensions are reversed, such that [get v [| a; b; c |]] in
  868.       C layout becomes [get v [| c+1; b+1; a+1 |]] in Fortran layout.

  870.       @since 4.06
  871.   *)

  873. ‌  val size_in_bytes : ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int
  874.   (** [size_in_bytes a] is the number of elements in [a]
  875.     multiplied by [a]'s {!kind_size_in_bytes}.

  877.     @since 4.03 *)

  879.   external get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> int -> 'a = "%caml_ba_ref_3"
  880.   (** [Array3.get a x y z], also written [a.{x,y,z}],
  881.      returns the element of [a] at coordinates ([x], [y], [z]).
  882.      [x], [y] and [z] must be within the bounds of [a],
  883.      as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.get};
  884.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  886.   external set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> int -> 'a -> unit
  887.     = "%caml_ba_set_3"
  888.   (** [Array3.set a x y v], or alternatively [a.{x,y,z} <- v],
  889.      stores the value [v] at coordinates ([x], [y], [z]) in [a].
  890.      [x], [y] and [z] must be within the bounds of [a],
  891.      as described for {!Bigarray.Genarray.set};
  892.      otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  894.   external sub_left: ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) t
  895.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  896.   (** Extract a three-dimensional sub-array of the given
  897.      three-dimensional Bigarray by restricting the first dimension.
  898.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.sub_left} for more details.  [Array3.sub_left]
  899.      applies only to arrays with C layout. *)

  901.   external sub_right:
  902.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t
  903.     = "caml_ba_sub"
  904.   (** Extract a three-dimensional sub-array of the given
  905.      three-dimensional Bigarray by restricting the second dimension.
  906.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.sub_right} for more details.  [Array3.sub_right]
  907.      applies only to arrays with Fortran layout. *)

  909.   val slice_left_1:
  910.     ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) Array1.t
  911.   (** Extract a one-dimensional slice of the given three-dimensional
  912.      Bigarray by fixing the first two coordinates.
  913.      The integer parameters are the coordinates of the slice to
  914.      extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_left} for more details.
  915.      [Array3.slice_left_1] applies only to arrays with C layout. *)

  917.   val slice_right_1:
  918.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t ->
  919.     int -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) Array1.t
  920.   (** Extract a one-dimensional slice of the given three-dimensional
  921.      Bigarray by fixing the last two coordinates.
  922.      The integer parameters are the coordinates of the slice to
  923.      extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_right} for more details.
  924.      [Array3.slice_right_1] applies only to arrays with Fortran
  925.      layout. *)

  927.   val slice_left_2: ('a, 'b, c_layout) t -> int -> ('a, 'b, c_layout) Array2.t
  928.   (** Extract a  two-dimensional slice of the given three-dimensional
  929.      Bigarray by fixing the first coordinate.
  930.      The integer parameter is the first coordinate of the slice to
  931.      extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_left} for more details.
  932.      [Array3.slice_left_2] applies only to arrays with C layout. *)

  934.   val slice_right_2:
  935.     ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) t -> int -> ('a, 'b, fortran_layout) Array2.t
  936.   (** Extract a two-dimensional slice of the given
  937.      three-dimensional Bigarray by fixing the last coordinate.
  938.      The integer parameter is the coordinate of the slice
  939.      to extract.  See {!Bigarray.Genarray.slice_right} for more details.
  940.      [Array3.slice_right_2] applies only to arrays with Fortran
  941.      layout. *)

  943.   external blit: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> unit
  944.     = "caml_ba_blit"
  945.   (** Copy the first Bigarray to the second Bigarray.
  946.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.blit} for more details. *)

  948.   external fill: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> 'a -> unit = "caml_ba_fill"
  949.   (** Fill the given Bigarray with the given value.
  950.      See {!Bigarray.Genarray.fill} for more details. *)

  952.   val of_array:
  953.     ('a, 'b) kind -> 'c layout -> 'a array array array -> ('a, 'b, 'c) t
  954.   (** Build a three-dimensional Bigarray initialized from the
  955.      given array of arrays of arrays.  *)

  957.   external unsafe_get: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> int -> 'a
  958.                      = "%caml_ba_unsafe_ref_3"
  959.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array3.get}, but bounds checking is not always
  960.       performed. *)

  962.   external unsafe_set: ('a, 'b, 'c) t -> int -> int -> int -> 'a -> unit
  963.                      = "%caml_ba_unsafe_set_3"
  964.   (** Like {!Bigarray.Array3.set}, but bounds checking is not always
  965.       performed. *)

  967. end

  969. (** {1 Coercions between generic Bigarrays and fixed-dimension Bigarrays} *)

  971. external genarray_of_array0 :
  972.   ('a, 'b, 'c) Array0.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t = "%identity"
  973. (** Return the generic Bigarray corresponding to the given zero-dimensional
  974.     Bigarray.
  975.     @since 4.05 *)

  977. external genarray_of_array1 :
  978.   ('a, 'b, 'c) Array1.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t = "%identity"
  979. (** Return the generic Bigarray corresponding to the given one-dimensional
  980.    Bigarray. *)

  982. external genarray_of_array2 :
  983.   ('a, 'b, 'c) Array2.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t = "%identity"
  984. (** Return the generic Bigarray corresponding to the given two-dimensional
  985.    Bigarray. *)

  987. external genarray_of_array3 :
  988.   ('a, 'b, 'c) Array3.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t = "%identity"
  989. (** Return the generic Bigarray corresponding to the given three-dimensional
  990.    Bigarray. *)

  992. ‌val array0_of_genarray : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array0.t
  993. (** Return the zero-dimensional Bigarray corresponding to the given
  994.    generic Bigarray.
  995.    @raise Invalid_argument if the generic Bigarray
  996.    does not have exactly zero dimension.
  997.    @since 4.05 *)

  999. ‌val array1_of_genarray : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array1.t
  1000. (** Return the one-dimensional Bigarray corresponding to the given
  1001.    generic Bigarray.
  1002.    @raise Invalid_argument if the generic Bigarray
  1003.    does not have exactly one dimension. *)

  1005. ‌val array2_of_genarray : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array2.t
  1006. (** Return the two-dimensional Bigarray corresponding to the given
  1007.    generic Bigarray.
  1008.    @raise Invalid_argument if the generic Bigarray
  1009.    does not have exactly two dimensions. *)

  1011. ‌val array3_of_genarray : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array3.t
  1012. (** Return the three-dimensional Bigarray corresponding to the given
  1013.    generic Bigarray.
  1014.    @raise Invalid_argument if the generic Bigarray
  1015.    does not have exactly three dimensions. *)


  1018. (** {1 Re-shaping Bigarrays} *)

  1020. ‌val reshape : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> int array -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t
  1021. (** [reshape b [|d1;...;dN|]] converts the Bigarray [b] to a
  1022.    [N]-dimensional array of dimensions [d1]...[dN].  The returned
  1023.    array and the original array [b] share their data
  1024.    and have the same layout.  For instance, assuming that [b]
  1025.    is a one-dimensional array of dimension 12, [reshape b [|3;4|]]
  1026.    returns a two-dimensional array [b'] of dimensions 3 and 4.
  1027.    If [b] has C layout, the element [(x,y)] of [b'] corresponds
  1028.    to the element [x * 3 + y] of [b].  If [b] has Fortran layout,
  1029.    the element [(x,y)] of [b'] corresponds to the element
  1030.    [x + (y - 1) * 4] of [b].
  1031.    The returned Bigarray must have exactly the same number of
  1032.    elements as the original Bigarray [b].  That is, the product
  1033.    of the dimensions of [b] must be equal to [i1 * ... * iN].
  1034.    Otherwise, [Invalid_argument] is raised. *)

  1036. ‌val reshape_0 : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array0.t
  1037. (** Specialized version of {!Bigarray.reshape} for reshaping to
  1038.    zero-dimensional arrays.
  1039.    @since 4.05 *)

  1041. ‌val reshape_1 : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array1.t
  1042. (** Specialized version of {!Bigarray.reshape} for reshaping to
  1043.    one-dimensional arrays. *)

  1045. ‌val reshape_2 : ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array2.t
  1046. (** Specialized version of {!Bigarray.reshape} for reshaping to
  1047.    two-dimensional arrays. *)

  1049. ‌val reshape_3 :
  1050.   ('a, 'b, 'c) Genarray.t -> int -> int -> int -> ('a, 'b, 'c) Array3.t
  1051. (** Specialized version of {!Bigarray.reshape} for reshaping to
  1052.     three-dimensional arrays. *)

  1054. (** {1:bigarray_concurrency Bigarrays and concurrency safety}

  1056.     Care must be taken when concurrently accessing bigarrays from multiple
  1057.     domains: accessing a bigarray will never crash a program, but unsynchronized
  1058.     accesses might yield surprising (non-sequentially-consistent) results.

  1060.     {2:bigarray_atomicity Atomicity}

  1062.     Every bigarray operation that accesses more than one array element is not
  1063.     atomic. This includes slicing, bliting, and filling bigarrays.

  1065.     For example, consider the following program:
  1066. {[open Bigarray
  1067. let size = 100_000_000
  1068. let a = Array1.init Int C_layout size (fun _ -> 1)
  1069. let update f a () =
  1070.   for i = 0 to size - 1 do a.{i} <- f a.{i} done
  1071. let d1 = Domain.spawn (update (fun x -> x + 1) a)
  1072. let d2 = Domain.spawn (update (fun x -> 2 * x + 1) a)
  1073. let () = Domain.join d1; Domain.join d2
  1074. ]}

  1076.     After executing this code, each field of the bigarray [a] is either [2],
  1077.     [3], [4] or [5]. If atomicity is required, then the user must implement
  1078.     their own synchronization (for example, using {!Mutex.t}).

  1080.     {2:bigarray_data_race Data races}

  1082.     If two domains only access disjoint parts of the bigarray, then the
  1083.     observed behaviour is the equivalent to some sequential interleaving of the
  1084.     operations from the two domains.

  1086.     A data race is said to occur when two domains access the same bigarray
  1087.     element without synchronization and at least one of the accesses is a
  1088.     write. In the absence of data races, the observed behaviour is equivalent
  1089.     to some sequential interleaving of the operations from different domains.

  1091.     Whenever possible, data races should be avoided by using synchronization to
  1092.     mediate the accesses to the bigarray elements.

  1094.     Indeed, in the presence of data races, programs will not crash but the
  1095.     observed behaviour may not be equivalent to any sequential interleaving of
  1096.     operations from different domains.

  1098.     {2:bigarrarray_data_race_tearing Tearing}

  1100.     Bigarrays have a distinct caveat in the presence of data races:
  1101.     concurrent bigarray operations might produce surprising values due to
  1102.     tearing. More precisely, the interleaving of partial writes and reads might
  1103.     create values that would not exist with a sequential execution.
  1104.     For instance, at the end of
  1105. {[let res = Array1.init Complex64 c_layout size (fun _ -> Complex.zero)
  1106. let d1 = Domain.spawn (fun () -> Array1.fill res Complex.one)
  1107. let d2 = Domain.spawn (fun () -> Array1.fill res Complex.i)
  1108. let () = Domain.join d1; Domain.join d2
  1109. ]}
  1110.     the [res] bigarray might contain values that are neither [Complex.i]
  1111.     nor [Complex.one] (for instance [1 + i]).
  1112. *)

One Level Up Top Level
